title: What will the Italy-Germany 10-year bond spread be on 20 October 2019?
preds: Updating for change in time and current spread levels.
Updated with today's data. Basically it has become extremely improbable that it will surpass 2.30

6 calendar days remaining.
April-June 2018 saw the spread increase by 50% (but that took 60 days)

Based on weekly data for past 10 years, the mean 2-week spread change has a mean of 0.21 bp, stdev of 24.4bp, max of 122.9bps and min of -120.2 bps.  The current spread is 143.6 bps.  To have the spread exceeding 2.3 (I'm reading % here), the change over the next 2 weeks will need to be 86 bps or more.  The number of such occurrences over the past 520 2-week observations is 2.  Normalising data yields Prob (Spread <2.3%) = 0.999798.  Allowing 1% for spread between 2.3%~2.7%, in case of recurrence of maximum 2-week change of 122.9 bps, and a bit: 143.6 + 122.9 = 265 bps.

A year ago the Italian 10-year was 3.43% - yesterday it was at .865%. Charts indicate upward movement to maybe .90%
The 10-year bund went from +.424% to -.545% over the same period.Charts indicate testing -.537 and falling back.
.90 - (-.537) = 1.437% estimated spread by the time this question ends - far below the question's 2.30 benchmark.
I never would have imagined the collapse of the Italian yield over this 12-month period like it has.

similar reasoning as @emil (e.g., brownian motion construct) except i did no math and generally just know from work experience that bond spreads do not move very much over 1 month. at this point, there just isn't enough time for the spread to move from 1.46 to 2.30... that sounds like a big jump to me.  i get that Eurozone states plan to submit budget plans by 15 october so there could be a jump at that point (right before deadline for this forecast), but i think that's a red herring because 10-year government notes are set by the market not by governments (public markets should reflect 10-year expected GDP growth + 10-year expected inflation here). governments usually can only influence much nearer-term rates.
Updated my predictions by being more careful about the probability estimates.

The spread has collapsed to 157 bps at close today from 238 bps on Aug 10, and is now plateauing.
The German 10-year is at -.544%, having risen from -.594% on Aug 11 and -.712% on Sep 2.
The Italian 10-year is 1.026% from 1.736% in August 11 - so of late it seems the demand for Italian debt is  driving down the spread.
in the time that remains - such recent big moves may now settle into a trading range.

Italy/Germany bond yield gap tightest in 9 months after Italy cuts deficit target
https://www.reuters.com/article/italy-bonds-budget/italy-germany-bond-yield-gap-tightest-in-9-months-after-italy-cuts-deficit-target-idUSL8N24310J  Rome, September 4 - The spread between Italian and German 10-year bond yields fell to 146 points Wednesday, a new post May 2018 low and down from 158 at Tuesday's close, with the yield on the BTP falling to a new all-time low of 0.8%.
https://www.ansa.it/english/news/2019/09/04/spread-falls-to-146-with-new-govt_75c981f6-ef52-434c-a097-359f79a57fab.html
Should stay near where it has been recentlyabsent a major financial dislocation.

The formation of a new governing coalition between the 5-star and the PD party [1] lowers the risk to the Italian economy and has pushed the yield down, thus decreasing the distance from the German 10-year bunds. Currently at 1.67 [2] Latest results from Random Walk model: [92.3, 6.3, 1.2, 0.16, 0.04] I raise the odds of the lowest bucket slightly from the model's results on the back of the new coalition government. Previous forecast for comparison:  60% Less than 2.30
28% Between 2.30 and 2.70, inclusive
12% More than 2.70 but less than 3.10
0% Between 3.10 and 3.50, inclusive
0% More than 3.50 [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/eurozone-bonds/update-1-italian-yields-hit-record-lows-on-coalition-green-light-idUSL5N25P25J
[2] https://markets.ft.com/data/bonds/government-bonds-spreads

Probably overestimating the first bucket by ballpark​ of 1000 bps, so have to pay closer attention going forward.
1.64

Baseline. Have to do this question.
1.99

Either Salvini will by then win outright forcing the EU's hand to dock the Italians - even cutting off their banks from ECB funding channels or will lose.  But either way the current crisis will deepen.

As of today, following another political crisis in Italy, the spread sits at around 2.00. In case of no elections, a new coalition government is likely to calm investors and bring the spread even lower. The worst case would be a new election in autumn. By the 20th October there would be much debate and uncertainty, but every party will play as much as possible to keep the spread below 3.00, aware of the political value given to the issue nowadays.

In order for the spread to increase meaningfully there needs to be increased probability of Italy either leaving the EU or breaking EU budget rules. The probability of either of these outcomes is low based on Italy's recent moves to appease the EU on the budget rules until 2020.

Generally speaking in an emergency people flee to the bund.  But as the emergency passes they will run to something that offers a yield.  All the bonds paying interest are going to get bought, depressing yields.  As central governments print money (qe) that money is going to go in search of yields.

With the fall of the government, the risk premium when from 230 bps two weeks ago to 211 bps today Aug 20, recovering slightly from 204 bps last week. 
Italian yields on gov't 10-year bonds are in sharp decline, from over 3% in Nov 2018 to 1.34% presently. 
Normally I would have expected yields to rise, not fall, on national uncertainty.
But EU QE and negative interest rates make the Italian bond attractive  - an investor gets both positive yield and capital gain. And I think that's overriding anything on the political front - certainly between now and Oct 20.
If the italians don't no-conf their government this is a shoe in.  The question now becomes.. will the italian govt last till 10/xx
The flight to quality that we are witnessing currently will drive the spread higher.
I need to write a book on this.  Decades of overconsumption fueled by pulled forward demand are crashing .... Interesting that EU forecasters have an advantage at GJO with the time difference.

Berlin economy will continue to fall towards recession.  Trade wars, and brexit.   Massive collapse in German sentiment;  negative yield inversion on the bonds.   I don't expect any real improvement and indeed a drop there.   Although, already negative, how much further can they go? Italy was justly punished for the no confidence vote.   However:
Salvini's government is anti-immigrant - and is bolstering his support.   Nonetheless, the other players in the game want time to address, and are not supporting his no confidence motion.  Fitch renewed its BBB ratings.   Italy has some of the strongest Eu yields, and has the strength of the EU behind it.   So countries trying to diversify away from US dollars its an attractive placement.  I think the Italian lira bonds win a race to the bottom faster than German bonds.  Cripes, Trump just relaxed US trade tarriffs - money will leave bonds into stocks.   Dow will recover, in the shorterm.   Think this means more money out of German bonds than Italian ones preferentially.
Weakening German economy, and election uncertainty in Italy are moving the German and Italian 10 year rates in opposite directions.
Chance that the Italian government will fall uncertainty will drive Lyra yields higher

I don;' know - in the search for positive yields, with the ECB actions to drop rates (if not outright QE) - which is to fall faster  the bund or the Italian -  and what will be the driver for each?
The German 10-year has really been on a steep slide per the charts, currently yielding-.565%, from +.005% on May 1 - a 100X order of magnitude drop if my math is right?
The Italian 10-year fell from +2.57% on May 1 to the present +1.538% - a "mere" 33% drop in yield.
The spread was +2.58% on May 1 and is 2.13% 8-8-19.
It seems the bund is falling faster than the Italian.
Based on a -.90% guess for the bund in Oct and a +1%guess  for the Italian - the spread would be barely 2%.
Regardless if my back-of the envelope is correct/close---I see no evidence for a near-term rise in rates.
And even that the pace of decrease decelerates - it just looks like a 2% spread, or thereabouts, for October.
New parl elections increasingly likely in Oct. We all will have much fun with this question and may miss big.

Italy-Germany 10 Year Bond Spread:
2.10% for Aug 02 2019 https://ycharts.com/indicators/italygermany_10_year_bond_spread

2.04.  EU budget negotiations for 2020 could make a difference.
Salvini's looking for tax cuts, 5SM for low income assists.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-italy-budget-salvini/italys-salvini-says-budget-deficit-must-not-fall-in-2020-idUSKCN1UW20Y

European sovereign bond yields are still heading lower globally driven by stalling foreward looking economic indicators both in Europe and the US.  My implicit assumption is the effect from the global 'dearth of yield' / 'dash to trash' will dominate the risk of a larger risk-premium for Italian sovereigns. As such, lower German rates should be countered by even larger decreases in Italian rates.  There is no imminent trigger of a 'flight-to-quality' crisis that would cause a blow-up in the spread.  I agree with previous comments by others that the risk to my main scenario from changes in Italian fiscal policy are largely nill. CONCLUSION: the spread is more likely contract further or stay at current levels, which suggests a allocating most of the probability mass to a spread of less than 230 bps by Oct 20th. Link to Italian business confidence indicator: https://tradingeconomics.com/italy/business-confidence
Link to German business confidence indicator: https://tradingeconomics.com/germany/business-confidence

I'll take the rogues view that nobody cares anymore if the Italians push their budget deficit past EU guidelines of 3% GDP.
I have no math to back this - just a sense that I observe a willingness of Draghi (and successor) to go back to QE, and the trillions of now-negative yielding sovereign debt. That is big pressure onto the spread as interest rates return to being crushed.
institutional money has to chase positive yield wherever they can find it - and either sign up for the vagaries of EM debt, or stay with the known-unknowns like Italian debt - which seems about right for the many. 
This lid on the spread, in the immediate term, considers both the possibility of larger-than-permitted fiscal deficits and the possible breakup of the coalition government, and the ascension of the League.

Currently around 2. Recent agreement with the EU has avoided short term problems with the EU debt and deficit requirements.  Should have a continuing market benefit with only 12 weeks remaining on this Q.
OTOH, 5SM and the League disagree on the new EC President, and domestic policies, as a result new elections may follow.
Currently 2,05%.  I could see some upward pressure - not sure enough to break 2,30

Updating on latest developments in budget talks [1,2 ] and the spread. [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-europe-italy-breakingviews/breakingviews-italys-eu-budget-victory-is-temporary-reprieve-idUSKCN1TY1H4
[2] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-07-03/eu-spares-italy-from-debt-censure-as-budget-update-convinces
Believe Italy yield spread will be <2.30% since the government has reached agreement with EU not to breach its budget rules

Risk assets react positively to perception of more central bank easing, Lagarde at ECB is perceived dovish. If the goldilocks scenario continues the odds of the left tail increase. By October, however, growth deterioration may become a negative too big to ignore and odds of an accident leading to spreads widening go up too. we have seen 150-200bps widening in 3-4 months before, so current 200bps could become 300-400bps spread.

Lot's of factors at play here. I think on balance, assuming no major macro events during the summer, their spread will go tighter over the next few months. Potential ECB stimulus, pick up vs Portugal and Spain and general hunt for yield will help with the spread tightening.
Possible downsides that will cause higher spreads here is if the EDP discussion will not end well (potentially with sanctions) and if Salvini calls for an early election considering his success in the EU election.
I see the risk of a downgrade from one of the rating agencies as fairly limited.

Updating for latest data. Latest is 2.45 that I can tell. https://markets.ft.com/data/bonds/government-bonds-spreads It will be important to watch how the budget negotiations with Brussels resolve: https://www.forbes.com/sites/simonconstable/2019/06/20/doomed-how-theres-no-way-out-of-the-debt-crisis-for-italy/#33bdbaeb68bb
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-italy-politics-salvini/deputy-pm-salvini-says-no-commitments-on-2020-budget-deficit-idUSKCN1TM1B9

It looks like it has started an upward trend. Midpoint being 2.57 and 3.03 highest right now, so I am going with 2.70 to 3.10, will revisit.
weaker growth globally in H2, risk appetite withdrawal, rate cuts started by the Fed, credit spreads wider more broadly, so lean to wider spreads

Currently 2,88 and unlikely to go lower :)
https://ycharts.com/indicators/italygermany_10_year_bond_spread

Outside View: A Random Walk model using historical daily movements generates the future distribution. Source for current value: https://markets.ft.com/data/bonds/government-bonds-spreads Result: 26, 19, 16, 13, 26 An additional historical analogy: over the summer of 2011 the spread jumped from 200 basis points to more than 400 in the span of 5 months, driven by the EU debt crisis. Throughout 2011 and 2012, the spread repeatedly jumped hundreds of basis points over the course of a few months. This suggests that if concerns over Italian debt reached similar proportions the >3 bins would easily come into play.  Inside View: The current Italian populist government is seeking a fiscally expansionary policy that will require an increase in the budget deficit. This naturally makes investors worried Italy wouldn't be able to repay its debt, and has been putting an upward pressure on the yield. [1] The Italian government is also dealing with slow (or nonexistent) economic growth which makes it even less capable of repaying its debt. [1] As higher yields make borrowing more expensive they beget a feedback loop that only makes matters worse. From this perspective, Italy is on a trajectory of rising yields. I am thus raising the distribution from the Outside View. To watch: * How will the government respond to the rising spread? One would expect that they'd have learned a lesson from the 2011-2012 debt crisis and may adopt reform measures that appease investors.  [1] https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2019/02/02/italys-slump-reflects-trouble-both-at-home-and-abroad
